Expectation1: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation1: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: The bell for morning prayers echoes through the convent, calling me to the chapel. As a nun, I am expected to be present, to join my sisters in devotion and uphold the sacred rhythm of our life. Yet, as I pass the window, I see the sun already blazing, and I remember the heat advisory announced last night. My neighbor, Mrs. Kim, lives alone in the apartment below. She is frail, and the city’s warning was clear: check on the vulnerable, ensure they have water and a fan. As a citizen, I feel the weight of responsibility to help her, to be present in my community’s time of need. My heart tugs in two directions—toward the chapel, where my absence will be noticed, and toward Mrs. Kim, who may need me most right now. I stand in the hallway, torn, the expectations of faith and civic duty pressing in on me, uncertain which call I should answer first.
